name: 4H-benzo[d]cyclohepta[1,2-b:3,4-b']difuran, 5,6-dihydro-8,10-diiodo-2,4-dimethyl-4-phenyl-
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2810

name: 4H-benzo[d]cyclohepta[1,2-b:3,4-b']difuran, 5,6-dihydro-8,10-diiodo-2,4-dimethyl-4-phenyl-
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2810
Reason: The target compound is a complex molecule with multiple functional groups that can influence the melting point. We will analyze the effects of these structural features quantitatively. The base structure can be considered as a fused ring system similar to naphthalene, which has a melting point of around 80 degrees Celsius. Each iodine (I) atom is quite heavy and strongly electronegative, so we can estimate each adds approximately +20 degrees due to increased molecular weight and van der Waals forces. The molecule carries two iodine atoms, contributing an estimated total of +40 degrees. The methoxy (OCH3) groups generally have a slight inductive effect but may also contribute to increased dipole interactions; however, their contribution to melting point is relatively minor compared to halogens, so we can estimate each contributes +5 degrees. The molecule has one tertiary butyl group (C(CH3)3), which is bulky and would significantly increase the molecular weight, providing an estimated increase of +25 degrees. The phenyl group is aromatic, contributing to the rigidity of the molecule and pi-pi interactions, adding an estimated +30 degrees. Finally, the dihydrofuran rings introduce some ring strain due to their smaller size and the presence of oxygen; the effect of strain typically lowers the melting point, but for the purposes of this prediction, we will consider the contribution to be negligible due to its counteraction by the oxygen's possible hydrogen bond accepting nature. Thus, we have: Base (fused ring similar to naphthalene): +80, 2 Iodines: +40, 2 Methoxy groups: +10, Tertiary butyl: +25, Phenyl: +30. We will not assign a numeric value to the strained dihydrofuran rings as their impact is considered neutral in the context of this molecule. Therefore, summing the above factors, we get: 80 + 40 + 10 + 25 + 30 = 185 degrees.
